competitive_intel:
## Available Competitive Intelligence

- Competition description: `../research/description.md`
- 5 top kernel notebooks in `../research/kernels/`

data_findings.finding: Problem: Pack 1-200 Christmas tree shapes into smallest square bounding box. Score = sum(s_n^2/n) for all n. Trees have x,y position and rotation angle. Lower score is better. Target: 68.919154
Tree shape: 15-vertex polygon. Tip at (0, 0.8), trunk bottom at (0, -0.2). Width: 0.7 at base, 0.4 mid, 0.25 top. Trunk: 0.15 wide, 0.2 tall. Total height: 1.0

Key C++ optimizer (tree_packer_v21): Uses squeeze, compaction, local search, simulated annealing, swap moves, multi-start with different angles. Compile: g++ -O3 -march=native -std=c++17 -fopenmp. Run with -n (iterations) and -r (restarts). Typical: n=5000-20000, r=16-256
Backward propagation technique: Start from N=200, remove boundary-touching trees one at a time to potentially improve smaller N configurations. Greedy deletion of trees that reduce bounding box most.
